xxl.core.cursors.distincts
Class NestedLoopsDistinct<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.distincts.NestedLoopsDistinct<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this distinct operator.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
NestedLoopsDistinct
public class NestedLoopsDistinct<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>

A nested-loops implementation of the distinct operator, i.e., all duplicates contained in a cursor will be removed. Depending on the specified memory size and object size as many elements of the input cursor as possible will be inserted into a temporal bag (typically located in main memory). To guarantee that no duplicates will be inserted into it, the bag is searched for duplicates with the help of a user defined predicate. If not all elements can be inserted into the bag they will be temporarily stored in a queue, that is typically resided in external memory, and will be inserted when the bag has been emptied due to calls to the next method of this class.

Example usage (1): 

   NestedLoopsDistinct<Integer> distinct = new NestedLoopsDistinct<Integer>(
       new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(21), 30),
       32,
       4
   );
   
   distinct.open();
   
   while(distinct.hasNext())
       System.out.println(distinct.next());
       
   distinct.close();
The input cursor shown in this example deliveres 30 randomly distributed integer numbers contained in the interval [0, 20]. The main memory size is set to 32 bytes and the object size to 4 bytes. So the list-bag generated by the default factory method that is used in this case as default is able to hold a maximum 3 elements in main memory. The remaining one element, that fits in main memory, is reserved for the comparison of two elements. Due to the fact that not all elements of the input cursor can be stored in the temporal main memory bag, the remaining elements will be stored in an array-queue returned by the factory method that is used as default. Normally this queue should be placed in external memory. Running this example shows that no duplicates are returned by this operator.

Note: If an input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, Bag, Queue, SortBasedDistinct, NestedLoopsDistinct

protected Predicate<? super E> predicate
An unary predicate determining if two elements are equal. If the returned value is true the given element and the next element of the internal used cursor that holds all remaining elements do match.

The maximum number of elements that can be stored in the bag returned by the function newBag.

Constructor Detail

NestedLoopsDistinct

public NestedLoopsDistinct(Iterator<? extends E> input,
                           int memSize,
                           int objectSize,
                           Predicate<? super E> predicate,
                           Function<?,? extends Bag<E>> newBag,
                           Function<?,? extends Queue<E>> newQueue)
                    throws IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new instance of the nested-loops distinct operator. The input iterator is wrapped to a cursor. Determines the maximum number of elements that can be stored in the bag used for the temporal storage of the elements of the input cursor: 
     maxTuples = memSize / objectSize - 1

Parameters:
input - the input iterator delivering the elements.
memSize - the maximum amount of available main memory (bytes) for the bag.
objectSize - the size (bytes) needed to store one element.
predicate - the binary predicate returning true if two elements are equal.
newBag - a parameterless function returning an empty bag.
newQueue - a parameterless function returning an empty queue.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if not enough main memory is available.

NestedLoopsDistinct

public NestedLoopsDistinct(Iterator<? extends E> input,
                           int memSize,
                           int objectSize)
                    throws IllegalArgumentException
Creates a new instance of the nested-loops distinct operator. The input iterator is wrapped to a cursor. Determines the maximum number of elements that can be stored in the bag used for the temporal storage of the elements of the input cursor: 
     maxTuples = memSize / objectSize - 1
Uses default factory methods for list-bags and array-queues. Determines the equality between two elements with the help of the default instance of the predicate Equal.

Parameters:
input - the input iterator delivering the elements.
memSize - the maximum amount of available main memory (bytes) for the bag.
objectSize - the size (bytes) needed to store one element.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if not enough main memory is available.
Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the nested-loops distinct operator, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the input iteration, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor<E>

close

public void close()
Closes the nested-loops distinct operator. Signals the operator to clean up resources, close the input cursor as well as the internally used bag and queue. After a call to close() calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the nested-loops distinct operator remains in the state "closed".

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor<E>

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Builds a temporal bag calling newBag.invoke() and stores as much distinct elements of the input cursor in this bag as possible. After that all remaining elements of the input cursor are inserted in the queue remainder. With the intention to guarantee that no duplicate elements are inserted in the temporal bag the bag's query method verifying each element concerning the specified predicate is called.
An element is only inserted if the result of the query method (a cursor) is empty. At last the bag's cursor method is called and the result cursor's reference is set to this cursor. If the result cursor contains any elements, true is returned, otherwise false. If the queue remainder contains further elements the whole procedure is returned by the next call to this method and at this time the elements inserted in the temporal bag are delivered by the queue.

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the nested-loops distinct operator has more elements.

nextObject

protected E nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be removed from the iteration, if next is called.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the nested-loops distinct operator to its initial state (optional operation). So the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again. The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent. This method resets the input iteration, closes the result cursor, sets it to null and clears the queue remainder.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<E>
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the nested-loops distinct operator.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the nested-loops distinct operator. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.
